title: Does anyone really know anything at all, except to the extent of the knowledge we have to learn from? When there’s still billions of things we don’t know? - Quora

response.answer_text: Firstly, even if we knew ‘everything’, human nature will force us to look for things we don’t know yet. We will always keep looking for things that are unknown to us, like we see in space exploration. Secondly, the question implicitly assumes there is a ‘whole’ of knowledge. There isn’t. What there is to know will always keep expanding (as well as things erode, fade away from knowledge (for example, the knowledge used to put men on the moon in 1969 is gone, we don’t know anymore how they did it). Ther are also languages found on thing like clay tablets we don’t know how to decypher. Once that was known, of course. There is no ulimate, complete body of knowledge.

Most of us know the millions of things that we need to know in order to survive and prosper, and those who don’t are often actively learning them. The ‘billions’ of things we don’t know tend to be those of much less immediate importance. However, many people are investigating some of those things. That’s called ‘science’, and we can expect it to make our lives significantly better as it progresses. But if you think there’s some important topic that we’re missing out on, then by all means tell us; and if you can make a case for it, a researcher might take it up.

We need to question what knowledge is, and whether there are different kinds of knowledge. From the question, it seems the concern is with the total sum of knowledge available to mankind. Much of this is scientific knowledge, and that is obviously something that has mostly been developed in recent centuries, through theorising and experimentation. However, there is possibly another type of knowledge, intuitive knowledge, that is said to be a matter more of perception than intellectual analysis. Some of the early achievements of humanity suggest insights into subtle energies and knowledge of building techniques still not fully understood. Early advances in medicine, the uses of plants, metallurgy, and astronomy also point the same way.

Actually we do know everything because we all have equal knowledge to the universal library of imagination. The reason why this knowledge seem crazy is because the chaos we live is so confusing that the truth seem impossible to prove.

Yes, there are countless things we don’t know and will never know and it makes no difference. Just live, love, and be happy. My greatest joys have come from my interactions with people, primarily children.
